title: MRF-UNets: Searching UNet with Markov Random Fields

sections.search space: We use UNet [ref]27 as the backbone. Generally speaking, UNet and other encoder-decoder networks usually contain three types of operations: Normal, Down and Up. We search for both size and width of the convolution kernel and summarize the search space in Table¬†1. For the original UNet that has 26 layers, our search space has about 4√ó10234superscript10234\times 10^{23} configurations in total. For a fair comparison, for manually designed architectures, e.g.¬†UNet [ref]27, UNet++ [ref]43 and BiO-Net , we use their templates and implement the Normal/Up/Down operations in the same way as our search space, but fix the kernel size to be 3. For automatically found architectures, e.g.¬†NAS-UNet [ref]32, MS-NAS , and BiX-Net , we do not make any modification and use their implementations directly. However, there exist discrepancies. For instance, we use transposed convolution for up-sampling while NAS-UNet [ref]32 uses dilated transposed convolution and BiX-Net  uses bilinear interpolation.
